results.title: Atanarjuat the fast runner
results.creator_credit: Zacharias Kunuk, Canadian Television Fund, Canadian Television Fund License Fee Program and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Hailed as the first feature ever in the Inuktitut language, this film won numerous accolades for its stunning cinematography and exceptional setting - ancient frozen lands of the Artic circle. Based on an olden Inuit legend, this fable is set at the dawn of the millennium, and is the story of a man, Atanarjuat, whose love for a woman (betrothed to another) sees him challenge his rival, enlisting the help of his powerful older brother. Romantic rivalry, jealousy, murder, rape and betrayal, all ensue as a menacing force - brought to their village by a shaman - beset the tribe. The period detail of the era is painstakingly recreated here, making the film, from an anthropological perspective, a fascinating view of a way of life untainted by Western influence. Shot of widescreen digital video on location in Igloolik, Nunavut, Canada.

results.title: In celebration
results.creator_credit: Lindsay Anderson, Ely Landau and Almo
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Atmospheric adaptation of David Storey’s emotionally charged play, about three sons who return to their Yorkshire mining town for their parent’s wedding anniversary - an event that stirs up suppressed resentment, childhood memories and bitterness, despite the men’s successful lives. Impressive performances from Alan Bates, James Bolam and Brian Cox who reprise their stage roles as the three middle class sons. Part of the American Film Theatre Collection.

results.title: The Man in the glass booth
results.creator_credit: Arthur Hiller, Ely Landau, Cinevision Ltee and Ely Landau Organization
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “American Film Theater = The American Film Theatre Collection”.
Searing adaptation made for the American Film Theatre collection, of the Robert Shaw play, about a wealthy Jewish man living in Manhattan who is beset by demons and paranoia. A survivor of the Holocaust, Arthur Goldman is one day kidnapped and shipped to Israel where he is tried for war crimes. But is this character the victim or the perpetrator? With its claustrophobic and minimalist setting, Arthur Hiller teases out the themes of guilt, paranoia, conspiracy theories and martyrdom. Maximillian Schell was nominated for an Academy Award for his portrayal of Goldman, but the adaptation itself was controversial, with Shaw removing his name from the credits, due to dissatisfaction with Edward Anhalt’s screenplay.

results.title: Walkabout (1970) [DVD]
results.brief_description: Nicolas Roeg’s lyrical tale about a sister (Jenny Agutter) and her young brother (Lucien John) left stranded in the Australian outback having survived their father’s attempt to destroy the family. They are rescued by a young First Nations man (David Gulpilil) who has journeyed into the vast desert on his walkabout - a tribal initiation into manhood. During their journey Gulpilil courts the young woman, though in her incomprehension she rejects his advances. The vision of paradise lost presented with an often surreal intensity is that of a European outsider, who sees white history as invasive and deeply destructive. Also stars John Meillon, Robert McDara, Pete Carver, John Illingsworth, Hilary Bamberger, Barry Donnelly, Noelene Brown and Carlo Machini. Cinematography by Nicolas Roeg. Screenplay by Edward Bond, based on the novel by James Vance Marshall. Edited by Antony Gibbs and Alan Pattillo. Music composed and conducted by John Barry. Also available on VHS [309075].

results.title: Feel like going home
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”, “Feel like going home” is Scorsese’s own directorial contribution, tracing the blues from the Mississippi Delta back to its roots in the Niger River, Mali. Musician Corey Harris acts as a guide along the journey, conducting interviews with a variety of musicians and engaging in song with several. Whilst examining the musical milieu of the Mississippi Delta, Scorsese addresses the work of Alan Lomax, the pioneering musicologist who recorded innumerable obscure American musicians and singers. Presents brilliant vintage footage of early blues men, such as Son House and John Lee Hooker whilst painting a picture of the rural poverty that dominated the lives of these future greats. Original performances include Willie King, Corey Harris, Taj Mahal, Keb Mo, Otha Turner, Habib Koite, Salif Keita, and Ali Farke Toure.

results.title: The Road to Memphis
results.creator_credit: Richard Pearce, Robert Kenner, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. On the road - how the early bluesmen made a living was touring from town to town on what became know as ‘The Chitlin Circuit’. Still living that dream is Bobby Rush who owns a bus and takes his show on the road and has “only been outta work 6 weeks in 41 years” and by his own admission he’s either crazy or just loves the music! Not strictly blues, Bobby serves to act as an illustration of some of the trials and tribulations experienced by legendary performers early in their careers, including the influence of the church. B.B. King, Ike Turner, Rufus Thomas, Rosco Gordon, Little Milton, Howlin’ Wolf, Little Milton, Fats Domino and Little Richard are some of the artists featured. Rosco Gordon takes a tour down Beale Street and recalls the past in a timely interview as he passes away at the end of filming, on a tour, in 2002. Memphis had one of the first radio stations on which African Americans appeared as announcers and performers - this proved to be a very lucrative business and a wider audience developed that also included white listeners. Sam Phillips, who is most well known for recording a 19 year-old Elvis, had been recording black artists for some four years before that. Jim Dickinson, musician/producer is also interviewed about the effect the music had on him. When Martin Luther King was assassinated Memphis city officials decided to tear down Beale Street causing an impact on the black history it represented. Broad appeal to white audiences came about in the 1968, culminating in an emotional 95% white audience in front of B.B. King at the Fillmore Auditorium - a new experience for B.B. and one that would mark a change in his audience for good. Ending with a live concert at the WC Handy Awards in 2002, this documentary is sure to inform and inspire.

results.title: The Soul of a man
results.creator_credit: Wim Wenders, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. In his inimitable interpretation of the documentary Wim Wenders directs in a mixed form of dramatic re-enactment, interviews, clips and footage combined with contemporary musicians performing their own interpretations of some of the songs of the original era. This work explores three particular blues artists and their legacy of great music - Blind Willie Johnson, Skip James and J.B. Lenoir. Beginning in outer space, we learn that on a record sent to represent the human race is a blues song by Blind Willie Johnson. Wenders constructs a narrative to illustrate the possible life and times of Blind Willie, narrated in first person by Laurence Fishburne. Wenders then cuts to a live recording/performance of some of the songs by artists such as Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds, Lou Reed, Beck, Cassandra Wilson, Lucinda Williams and The Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, amongst others, throughout the biographical storytelling. Skip James was another extremely influential artist from the 1920/30s and his story is also re-created - how he won a competition to make a record but never saw any royalty money from it and then left music to start a ministry in the church. results.title: Warming by the devil's fire
results.creator_credit: Charles Burnett, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. Kidnapped by Uncle Buddy, on his way to be saved from the devil by being baptised, a young 11 year-old boy gets a life education on exactly what it is he is going to be ‘saved’ from. Through a re-telling of this young boy’s journey travelling the Deep South, his education becomes the viewers’ with a narration (by Carl Lumbly) of the boy as an adult recalling this past he will never forget. The history of the African American musician is his lesson, starting out in New Orleans and the blues music that stemmed from early 1900 to the 1940s turns into, as the director says, a ‘story that gives you the impression of the blues’. Inserted in the ‘educational’ narrative is a combination of archival footage of the period, original performances and stills. The influence of the church and gospel music is covered and the work also includes details of female performers whose powerful music and voices transcend time and place, such as Bessie Smith, Victoria Spivey, Ma Rainey, Dinah Washington and Sister Rosetta Thorpe. Others featured include Willie Dixon, Sonny Boy Williamson, Son House, John Lee Hooker and Muddy Waters amongst many others. Cast includes Tommy Redmond Hicks and Nathaniel Lee Jr. with an original score by Stephen James Taylor.

results.creator_credit: Clint Eastwood, Alex Gibney, Margaret Bodde, Reverse Angle International and Vulcan (US)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Blues Collection = Martin Scorsese presents The Blues a musical journey [DVD]”.
Part of Martin Scorsese’s “The Blues Collection”. An intimate series of interviews with some of the big names in piano blues music in America with director, and fellow pianist, Clint Eastwood. Starting out with Ray Charles and featuring clips and photographs of musicians of the last century, Eastwood’s journey is sure to inspire a new generation as he asks “Who were your influences…?” Whilst guitar seems to take centre stage in modern blues, it could be argued that it was piano that lead to the popularisation of the form with hit makers such as Ray Charles, Fats Domino and Duke Ellington leading the way. Refreshingly includes some footage and interviews with female musicians. Some of the legends seen performing are: Ray Charles, Dr. John, Fats Domino, Prof. Longhair, Nat King Cole, Dave Brubeck, Marcia Ball, Jay McShann, Art Tatum, Big Joe Turner and Duke Ellington among many others.

results.creator_credit: Michael Bay, Jerry Bruckheimer and Jerry Bruckheimer Films
results.brief_description: Resoundingly derided drama about the invasion on Pearl Harbor by the Japanese, this film, directed by Michael Bay, nonetheless contains some impressive sequences, mostly the expertly executed and detailed battle scenes. Less engaging is the love triangle between two pilots, and the girl they both fall for. Cast includes Ben Affleck, Josh Hartnett, Kate Beckinsale, Cuba Gooding Jnr, Jon Voight.
